title: 104_hr1114
content: AUTHORITY FOR 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS TO LOAD MATERIALS INTO SCRAP PAPER BALERS AND PAPER BOX COMPACTORS. The Fair Labor Standards Act now allows 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards and cannot be operated while being loaded. Employees aged 16 and 17 can load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards and have an on-off switch controlled by employees aged 18 or older. Employees aged 16 and 17 can load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards. The on-off switch must be controlled by employees aged 18 or older, and a notice must be posted stating that only 16- and 17-year-old employees can load the machines, while those under 18 cannot operate or unload them. Employees under 18 can only load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors, not operate or unload them. Employers must report any injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving these machines. The Secretary will publish safety standards for these machines. Employees under 18 must only load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors, not operate or unload them. Employers must report any injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving these machines for the Secretary to assess safety standards. The reports should include employer and employee details. Employees under 18 must only load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors, not operate or unload them. Employers must report any injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving these machines to the Secretary within 10 days. Reports should include employer and employee details, incident date, injury description, and equipment details. Employers must report injuries or deaths of employees under 18 involving scrap paper balers and paper box compactors to the Secretary within 10 days. The Secretary cannot solely rely on these reports to determine violations of child labor laws and must conduct investigations before making such determinations. Reporting requirements expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2. Civil money penalty amended for Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Section 16(e) is updated to include penalties for violations of section 12 or section 13(c)(5). SEC. 3. Construction clarification for apprentices and student learners exemption in section 570.63 of title 29, Code of Federal Regulations.
